channel.title: A Little 4-Bit Adder
channel.description:
Well, I started this project a couple days after I first messed with redstone. Eventually I lost good ideas so I figured I'd make a small calculator, as everyone had done. I only added support for 4 bit adding because anything higher would've been too annoying to add.
The output and right input is backwards because I didn't think at the very start, nor did I at the end. And I made it really anti-compact just because I wanted to make it look like a circuit board :D. The equation in the picture is 1111 (15) + 100 (4), resulting in 10011 (19)
[img]http://img88.imageshack.us/img88/1779/mccalculator4.png[/img]
The whole thing took a little under 24 hours (from Saturday night to Sunday afternoon), so it was just a small thing I did for fun.
~Lin

item.title: A Little 4-Bit Adder
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

[quote=“shrogg, post:10, topic:391102”]YAY!
another moparscaper joining the vast world of redstone
I have made a computer that can run multible operations automatically, so if you need any help with anything, just ask me

A quick bit of critisizim, THE WIRING.
WHAT WENT WRONG, i really want to know how it ended up in a circle like that.
its… well… odd?

It’s too bad that Notch hasn’t implemented IC chips as blocks, instead requires us to create them using redstone wire. :\

After making a few CPUs and clocks using redstone, it made me think about the idea of IC’s, and i really dont like the idea of them, it would ruin all of the fun with redstone.[/quote]

IC chips are meant to compact electronics so there is no need to implement a hundred of continuous wires to create one. You wouldn’t have to use them if you don’t want to, but they would be there to allow people to make bigger things without the hassle of creating gigantic contraptions.
